dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STEVEN, a cardiothoracic surgeon, around 45 years old, MATTHEW, an anaesthetist of around 55, and three SURGICAL NURSES are leaning over the chest of a patient. They are performing open heart surgery. We follow the surgical instruments as they explore the patient’s internal organs The surgeon’s movements are precise, considered. The procedure unfolds in perfect synchronicity. No one misses beat. The only sounds are the clink of metal instruments, doctors’ breathing, and the electronic beep of the heart monitor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven and Matthew stand at a sink, washing their hands. Their scrubs are splattered with blood. The overhead ligh is harsh. The anaesthetist takes his watch out of his poc and puts it on. The surgeon takes the anaesthetist’s hand studies his watch. Steven Nice watch. Matthew Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What’s the water resistance?

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: 200 metres. Steven It also has a date display.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Yes, it does.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I might have gone for a metal strap instead of a leather strap.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Oh, really?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes. I think I’d prefer a metal strap. I’ve had this one for years and it’s as good as new. He shows Matthew the watch he’s wearing, which has a meta strap. Matthew studies it carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What’s the water resistance?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: 100 metres.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: How long have you had it?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Nine years. I’m a bit bored of it, actually. I’ve been thinking about getting a new one for a while now.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Think about it. We can go together to the place where I bought it. If I tell them you’re a colleague of mine, a friend, they'll definitely give you a better price. Both the owner and his father have been patients of mine, so I know them quite well. Think about it. Steven looks at Matthew’s watch again. He smiles almost imperceptibly and with a nod assures Matthew that he will think about it. The anaesthetist leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven unlocks the door to his office. A small room with chairs, a two-seater sofa, and a metal locker. He opens t locker, takes off his white coat and hangs it up. He puts a blazer and picks up his leather briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven sits in a Burger King, waiting for someone. He sip soft drink. There are barely any customers, it’s a slow t of day. On the table in front of him is a small piece of apple pie. MARTIN, a teenage boy, rushes over to Steven's table. His face is flushed and his T-shirt is patchy with sweat. Martin, around 15, is dressed like a typical teena He has a nondescript face, not particularly likeable but unlikeable either.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Sorry to keep you waiting. Did you eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’ve just had some apple pie.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I grab something to eat before we go? I’m starving.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Sure. No problem.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Are you sure you don’t want anything? Chicken wings?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: No, thank you. I’m fine. Do you have money? I can give you some.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No, I’ve got money, thanks. I’1l be right back. The boy leaves. Steven’s mobile phone rings. He switches ringer to silent and ignores the call. He watches the boy he waits for his order. Martin comes back. Steven watches Martin while he eats. The boy eats very methodically. He folds his napkin neatly and puts it to one side.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Did you get a haircut?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes. Do you like it?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It looks great. A beat of silence.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aren’t you going to eat your chips?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m saving them ‘til last.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I really like chips. I always save them for last.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I do that too. Martin finishes his burger then starts eating his chips. leaves half of them untouched and pushes his plate away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we go?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’ve got French class in an hour. Will I be back in time?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes, definitely. Don’t worry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven and Martin are standing beside the car. It is park near the sea. The weather is fine, the sea calm. A few pe are swimming. The boy takes off his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Sorry I was late today, Steven.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I was at a friend’s house. He got a new motorbike and I wanted to check it out. He took me for a ride, that’s why I was late.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: He even let me ride it for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I hope you were wearing helmets.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, of course we were. We weren’t going very fast anyway. A beat of silence.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I got you a present. Steven hands Martin a small box. The boy opens the box. Inside is a new watch. It’s the same one the anaesthetist wearing.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I don’t know how to thank you. It’s really nice. Thank you so much. Can I give you a kiss? The doctor nods. The boy kisses him and strokes his cheek slips the watch onto his right wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It’s water resistant up to 200 metres.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Fantastic. Does this come off? I'd prefer a leather strap.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It comes off, yes. You can put on any strap you like. But metal ones are more hard-wearing, that’s why I got you the metal strap. It’s more expensive too.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes. Thank you so much. EXT. STEVEN’S HOUSE - GARDEN - NIGHT A detached suburban house. Steven is sitting at the garde table with his two children: KIM, a girl of 14, and BOB, year old boy. A hush hangs in the air. The garden is perfectly manicured and the flowers are well tended. The doctor's wife brings out a dish with meat and starts to s everyone. She is around 40, rather beautiful. Her name is ANNA.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Dad, do you remember Claire, my friend from school?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: It’s her birthday and she’s having a party in two weeks. At her place. She’s invited most of the class. Can I go?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: We'll see.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Dad, if Kim goes can I go with her?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I don’t know, darling. Your mother and I will discuss it and we’ll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say they can go. Claire is a very nice girl. She’s the girl we met at the mall with her parents who asked you about becoming a doctor. The one who wants to be a cardiologist.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes, I remember.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: How was work today?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Fine. How about you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I've decided to make a few changes at the clinic. I’m going to get it painted, buy a new sofa. I’m thinking of doing it now before my receptionist goes on leave. Did I tell you she’s pregnant?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes. Good for her.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes. She finally succeeded. She’s thrilled. (Looking at her son.) Look at you, all hunched over. You'll strain your back like that, how many times do I have to tell you? And your hair is practically trailing in your food.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Bob, you promised me you'd get a haircut and you still haven’t done it.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'll get a haircut.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Not tomorrow, Dad. After the party.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I like his hair long. He has lovely hair.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: What about mine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have lovely hair too. We all have lovely hair. And darling, you have to go to the dentist. It’s been over six months, it’s time to get your teeth cleaned again. I’1l book an appointment for Friday afternoon. Is Friday afternoon all right? Do you have any appointments at the hospital?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: No. Friday after five is fine. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is sitting in front of the mirror, removing her make Steven is lying in bed in his pyjamas, looking at somethi on his phone. The room is dimly lit.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I bought that dress you liked. I can wear it tomorrow. I can’t show it to you now, it needed some alterations. I’m picking it up tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: The black one?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: It was the black one you liked, wasn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes. The other one looked great on you too, but I think the black one was perfect.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m worried it’s a bit too short. I'd like it better if it was below the knee.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You’ve got great legs. You’ve got the most beautiful legs of any ophthalmologist anywhere in the world.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Let me think, yes, of all the cardiologists in the world, there's no doubt at all, you are most definitely the biggest flatterer of them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that a problem?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No, that’s not a problem. And that’s why tomorrow I’m going to bake a lemon cake and nobody’s going to eat any of it, but you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Not even the kids?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Not even the kids. Did I tell you about my receptionist?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: If Kim was a bit more dependable, she could help arrange the appointments at the clinic until Christina gets back.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Kim could handle that just fine.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I hope so. Did I tell you, Bob announced me the other day he wants to be an ophthalmologist.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes, you did. Bob would be a coal miner if you were one too. Do you mind if I turn the light off? Anna gets up and kisses him on the mouth for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No. They carry on kissing with the lights on. Anna pulls Stev pyjama bottoms off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven is examining a PATIENT. There is a knock at the do Steven’s SECRETARY enters.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Doctor. There’s a boy for you outside. He says it’s urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’ll be out in five minutes. Tell him to wait. 10 INT. HOSPITAL - CORRIDOR —- MORNING Steven sees Martin waiting for him in the corridor. He ta him to one side.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Look I’ve told you, it’s best not to come to the hospital without calling me first.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You're right. I’m sorry. I just wanted to thank you again and show you the new strap I got for my watch. I swapped the metal strap for a leather one. I’m sorry, I didn’t mean to put you in an awkward position. Bye. The boy walks away.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Martin. Come here. What kind of strap did you get?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (Without turning his head) Brown leather. The doctor hurries after the boy and catches up with him.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Show me. Martin hesitates at first, then shows him the watch.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s very nice.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Do you really think so? Or are you just being polite?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I really like it. Next time you want to come here, please call me first. You have my number. It’s for your own good. I might be with a patient or in surgery or ina meeting. There’s no point you waiting around if I can’t see you. I’m telling you for your own good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Matthew walks past, holding a patient’s file. to Steven and puts on his reading glasses.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Good morning, Matthew.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Could you please take a quick look at this. He shows Steven the file.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Of course, Matthew. Please leave it on my desk. I’1l have a look ina minute. Martin looks at the anaesthetist.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: We've got the same watch. The anaesthetist turns to look at Martin, who watch.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Let me introduce you. This young man is one of my son’s classmates. I ran into Martin and his parents at the mall last week. He told me he’s very interested in medicine. He wants to be a cardiologist. I suggested he drop by some time, so he can see what being a doctor is really about. Martin, this is Matthew, a great friend of mine and an excellent anaesthetist.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: That's great. Nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you too. Steven, I’m going to leave it on your desk. Let me know when you’re ready. The anaesthetist walks off.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I’ve got to go back in now. We'll talk on the phone to arrange our next meeting. All right? 10. He comes over shows him his  11 11.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Okay. INT. STEVEN'S HOUSE - KIM’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Steven, dressed in a suit and bow tie, sits opposite Kim. is doing voice exercises. She exhales slowly, controlling diaphragm, then takes a deep breath and runs through a se of vocal scales. Bob has just had a shower and is combing hair very thoroughly and very slowly. Steven watches his daughter with pride, holding her gaze she performs her vocal drills. When she finishes, Steven claps, stands up, and kisses her on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I think your breathing has really improved over the last few months.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: That’s what the choirmaster said too.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Did you tell him to move you closer to the front?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Yes, I did. He said he’1ll see what he can do. Steven turns to Bob.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Did you water the plants, Bob?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Mum said she was going to water them.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Your mother works very hard. That’s why we said it would be nice to help her as much as we can, and we agreed that Kim would take care of walking the dog and you would take care of the plants.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'll do the dog and Kim can do the plants.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You're too young to be wandering around at night by yourself.  12. Bob gives the comb to Kim.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Thanks for the comb.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: You’re welcome. Bob leaves the room. The door opens and Anna walks in.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: We've got to go.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Tell Bob to water the plants now that the sun has gone down.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’ve watered them already. Come on, we're going to be late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven is at the podium giving a speech. The conference h is quite evidently full of doctors.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: A full 22 years have passed since the German cardiologist Andreas Gruentzig performed the first coronary angioplasty, on 16 September 1977. Today, that first patient is still alive and well. Dr. Gruentzig, however, had an unfortunate accident and met with an untimely end. In short, he is one of those rare cases where one can say: “The operation was a success, but unfortunately the doctor didn’t make it.” Scattered laughter in the audience. The doctor chuckles a takes a sip of water before he continues.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In the two decades that have passed since that first coronary angioplasty, many things have changed. The indications for angioplasty are more widespread, alternatives to the classic balloon method have been developed, and an angioplasty during the acute phase of a heart attack is practically a routine operation nowadays. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But now let’s touch upon the importance, both for us doctors and for our patients, of the development and use of the stent. Anna watches her husband with pride. Matthew, sitting nex her, gets up.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: I'm going for a cigarette. I’1l be at the bar. Come find me when it’s over.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven is talking to Anna, Matthew and an ELDERLY MAN, wh holding a flamboyant cocktail.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY MAN
dialogues.text: The guy who made it told me what was in it. I can’t remember now but it’s very refreshing. Would you like one?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY MAN
dialogues.text: Try it. It’s really delicious. Use this straw, I haven’t touched it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: He hasn’t had a drink in three years. High GGT and elevated transaminases.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY MAN
dialogues.text: Good on you for not drinking. Steven smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Well, I wouldn’t say no toa cocktail, if you’re still offering.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY MAN
dialogues.text: Of course. I’1l get you one right away.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I think we should go soon.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: It’s early.  14.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: He’s got surgery in the morning and he needs to get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: It’s still early.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: We've got surgery in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Fine, okay. How are the kids?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: They're doing very well. Bob started piano lessons and the teacher says he’s really talented. Now we need to buy him one so that he can practise at home, but I haven’t got round to it. I’m renovating the clinic. I’m on the phone all day.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Our daughter started menstruating last week.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: (awkwardly) Great.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes. She was a little scared, but she’s okay now. You haven’t seen her in ages.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Not since last summer. At that school choir concert.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You’1l have to come over for dinner one night. You really shouldn't stay late either. Just drink that cocktail you ordered and get yourself home. You have to be at the hospital in six hours. Shall we go, darling?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven is eating an ice cream with Martin. The doctor sta at the boy’s wrist as he eats his ice cream.  15.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You're not wearing your watch.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, I took it off to take a shower and left it at home.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It’s water resistant up to 200 metres.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s right. I forgot.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: If you don’t like it, we can go back to the shop and you can choose one that you do like.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No, I really like it. I just took it off to take a shower and forgot to put it back on, that’s all. Martin carries on eating his ice cream. It’s quite clear the subject is closed.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Do you have many friends?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Not that many. I don’t think people can have a lot of friends. I mean, it’s difficult. The important thing in life is to have good friends, not lots of friends. That’s what my dad used to tell me.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Your father was absolutely right.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, I know. I have a very good friend from school who plays basketball. We go and play together sometimes. And a friend who lives in France. I don’t see him very often. He usually comes in the summer with his family. He’s a great guy, very polite, lots of hobbies. I really miss him. I also consider my mum to be a friend. I know it might sound strange, but ever since my dad died we’ve become very close, me and my mum. We talk about things, lots of things. She helps me as much as she can with a lot of stuff. And I help her too.  16.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I'd like to ask you a favour. Only if you want to of course, I don’t want you to feel any pressure or obligation. It just seemed to me like a good idea, so I thought I'd ask. He hesitates for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd like you to come by my house one day. To meet my wife and children. I think you’d all get along really well, especially with Bob. They’re both lovely kids, I think you'll get along great. What do you think? Like I said, I don’t want to pressure you, come only if you'd genuinely like to. Martin looks at him for a few seconds without saying anything.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Are you serious? I'd love to come to your house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin enters the front garden of Steven’s house. He is carrying a bunch of flowers and a plastic bag. He rings t doorbell. Anna opens the front door.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. You must be Martin.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That's right. These flowers are for you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, Martin. Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin goes out into the back garden with Anna. Steven wa over to greet him.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Hi, Martin. Did you find the house all right?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, it was very easy.  17 17.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You’ve met Anna. Now let me introduce you to my children. This is Bob. And this is Kim.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Very nice to meet you. I’ve brought you some little gifts.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: That’s very kind of you. Martin takes two small boxes out of his plastic bag and g them to Bob and Kim. They start unwrapping the presents.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It’s a key ring with a musical note on it for Kim, because I know she likes music. And one with a smiley face for Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What lovely key rings. Now let’s get a move on and eat before the food gets cold. Are you hungry, Martin?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m starving. INT. STEVEN'S HOUSE - KIM’S BEDROOM - AFTERNOON Martin is sitting on the edge of the bed. Bob is sitting to him. Bob is staring at Martin’s shoes, which are ident to his own - probably another gift from Steven. Kim is standing by the wardrobe. Martin stares at a photograph o Kim, lying on a beach in a swimsuit. A child’s leg, proba Bob's, is also visible beside her in the picture.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: How long have you been in the choir, Kim?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Two years. Since I was 12. Do you like singing?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I love it. But I haven’t got a very good voice.  18.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Have you got hair under your arms yet?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: I just got my first period.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I light a cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You'd better not.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: It’s all right. Just go over by the window. Martin goes over to the window and smokes a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Can you sing us something?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: What, now?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes. Anything you like.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Not right now.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: She's embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: No I’m not. I just don’t feel like it. When did you start smoking?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Eight months ago. I was over at a friend’s place, it was a party actually, and we’d had way too much to drink and a girl offered me a cigarette and I said “why not” and lit up. That was a mistake. I regret it, but it’s too late now. I’m addicted.  19.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Can you show me the hair under your arms?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Sure. Martin shows Bob his underarm hair.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You haven’t got that much. Have you seen how hairy my dad is?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: He’s got three times more hair than you do.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: You've got a great body.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Thanks. An awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you want to go out for a walk? It’s a really nice day.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I'd rather stay here and listen to music. Bob picks up his headphones and an MP3 player.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Is that my MP3 player or yours?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Mine. You've asked me a million times. And don’t you dare take this one and lose it as well, because Dad said he’s not going to buy us new ones.

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What kind of music do you listen to?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: All kinds.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I‘m into metal and punk. What about you?  18 19 20 20.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I think all kinds of music are worth listening to. It depends on my mood and what I’m doing.. Bob puts his headphones on before Martin can finish his sentence.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: I'll come for a walk, if you like. We can take the dog with us. If you don’t mind.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I'd rather it was just the two of us. I always get nervous around dogs, in case they get into a fight with another dog. Separating dogs that are fighting scares me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin and Kim are walking along the road. There is an awkward distance between them and they both stare straigh ahead. Martin has one hand in his jacket pocket and a cigarette in the other. Kim walks a few steps behind him, watching him. She picks up her pace and catches up with Martin. She undoes her ponytail and shakes out her hair. EXT. PARK —- AFTERNOON Martin is sitting on a bench watching Kim. She stands fac him, singing a song. Martin nods his head in time with th music. Kim sways as she sings, not quite dancing. She hol lit cigarette in one hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin is sitting on the sofa. Kim sits next to him. Anna opposite them, is serving lemonade. On the table is a pla with some carrot cake. The dog is staring at the cake. Bo still has his headphones on.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Is this homemade lemonade?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It’s amazing. My mother makes lemonade too. But she hasn’t made it in a while. I’1l ask her to make some. I love lemonade.  21. He drains his glass of lemonade and refills it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The kids’ rooms are amazing. So big and bright. I told Bob to put a pull-up bar in his bedroom doorway. I’ve got one and I do a few pull- ups every time I walk past.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: That’s a great idea.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. Pull-up bars in doorways are dangerous. You might fall.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: If you attach it to the door frame properly, you won’t fall.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Okay. If we get one, we’ll ask you to come help us put it up.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: With pleasure. You know this whole house is really amazing.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You're welcome to spend the night, if you like. We can easily fit a mattress on the floor next to Bob’s bed. You can play together in the morning and I'll drop you back home tomorrow afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, but I’d rather go home tonight. I don’t like leaving my mother by herself. She wouldn’t mind if I told her I was spending the night here, but I'd better not.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Whatever you like.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Can I have a piece of cake please?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Of course you can. What about you guys?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: No.  21 22 Bob doesn’t respond. INT. STEVEN'S HOUSE - BEDROOM - NIGHT. 22. Anna is in the en-suite bathroom, flossing her teeth. Ste is already in bed.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What a charming boy.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Isn't he?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes, very. How did his father die?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Car crash.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You should tell him to come round again. The doctor’s mobile phone rings. He ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I will. He'll be great company for Bob. I thought next time I could take them both out somewhere, for a bike ride.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Darling, you should get that. It might be the hospital. Steven answers his phone. It’s Martin. Steven gets up and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven goes out into the corridor. He tries to speak quie

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Hello. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I'm fine, Martin. Has something happened?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No. I just called to tell you I had a wonderful time today.  23.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I’m very pleased to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes. I thought I should return the favour, so I'd like to invite you to dinner. At my house. My mother will be delighted to see you. She hasn’t seen you in two years, not since the hospital. I asked her if she'd like you to come for dinner one day and she said she'd like that very much. She’ll bake a meat pie.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: That's very kind of you. We’1ll do that someday.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Tomorrow night. I told her already. I've asked her to make meat pie and lemonade. I’1l be home by eight- thirty. Around nine?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: All right. Around nine.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I can buy some non-alcoholic beers, if you like.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: No, there’s no need.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I‘1l buy four and if you don’t drink them it doesn’t matter. My mother will drink them, or some other guest another day. So I’1ll see you tomorrow at nine. Good night and sorry to disturb you. Are Kim and Bob asleep?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m going to sleep now, too. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Good night.  23 24 25 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven pulls off his bloodied surgical gloves. He washes hands and then applies steriliser. Matthew, standing besi him, takes off his disposable hat, gloves, and surgical m and throws them in the bin.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: A friend of mine brought me a huge steelhead the other day. I thought I'd barbecue it. Do you and Anna want to come over for lunch on Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I’d love to. I’1l talk to Anna tonight to check we can make it and let you know.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Does Anna eat fish?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes, she does.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: I’m only asking because she seems like quite a picky eater.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: No, she isn’t. She loves fish.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Perfect. Then you must come. Tell her I'll be offended if you don’t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven approaches his car. The car park is fairly dark. Steven gets into his car and switches on the engine. As h pulls away, he sees a figure moving behind some parked ca It looks like Martin. He’s wearing the same jacket as Mar but we can’t see his face. As Steven drives towards him, figure runs towards the fire escape, opens the door, and disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven, Martin and MARTIN’S MOTHER have just finished din Martin’s mother is around 45 years old, a little plump, a has a beautiful face. She is dressed rather formally and heavily made up. The living room is spacious and decorate a conventional style. Everything is just so. Martin drain glass of lemonade. His mother clears away the dishes and takes them into the kitchen.  25.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Did you come to the hospital today?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No. I was at school, then I went to the gym and my French class. Weren’t you at the hospital today?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I was, but I was really busy. I just wondered whether you came by and couldn’t find me. Martin’s mother returns.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I'd like us to watch a film together, if you don’t mind.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: I'd gladly watch a film.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I have to be getting home soon. I can’t be out too late. I didn’t tell my wife I’d be late tonight and she might get worried.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: You could call her. In any case, if you feel tired we can stop the film, you can go home and we can watch the rest next time you come.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Please. We've rented my favourite film. It was my father’s favourite film too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven, Martin, and Martin’s mother are sitting on the so watching the film. She looks rapt. Martin yawns.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I think I’1l go to bed. I’m tired. Besides, I’ve got to get up early tomorrow to finish my homework. I’m sorry I can’t watch the end of the film with you. He gives them both a kiss and hug.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good night.  26.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Good night. Sitting on the sofa side by side, Steven and Martin’s mot carry on watching the film for a while.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: He really loves you, you know. He talks about you a lot.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I love him too.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Have you been married long?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: 16 years.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: You have lovely hands.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Most doctors have beautiful hands. So white and soft and clean.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Yes. I remember your hands from back when I used to visit my husband at the hospital. In fact, I even told him about your hands and he agreed. “You're right, he has beautiful hands,” he said.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Do you remember me coming to the hospital?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: I was a bit heavier then. And my hair was brown.  She moves 27.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: I got tired of it. I dyed it about a month ago. Did you prefer me with brown hair? Like it was back then?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I think it’s nicer now.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Yes. I agree. Do you like the film?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s good.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: It gets better. You’ll see. Would you like some dessert?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: Maybe later, then. You did eat a lot. closer to him. MARTIN'S MOTHER (CONT’D) Can I have a closer look at your hands? Steven looks embarrassed. Reluctantly, he extends a hand. Martin’s mother looks at the doctor’s hand. She kisses it momentarily, almost reverently. Then again and again, all over. She sticks his whole thumb in her mouth. He stands up. MARTIN'S MOTHER (CONT’D) Don't be afraid. He’s definitely asleep. There’s nothing to be afraid of. In any case, he wants this as much as I do, you know.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I have to go. It’s late. Thank you for dinner. I have to go. Have a good night.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN'S MOTHER
dialogues.text: I’m sorry if I made you feel awkward. I didn’t mean to. But I won’t let you leave until you've tried my tart. I made it for you specially. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 27 28. MARTIN’S MOTHER (CONT'D) It’s a caramel tart with custard cream. I’ll bring you some now. Please, sit down.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I’m afraid I really have to go. Good night. The doctor gets his coat and bag and walks out. INT. HOSPITAL - STEVEN’S OFFICE - MORNING Steven walks into his office. Martin is there, sitting in chair. The doctor is startled to see him. He stands in th doorway holding his bag. Martin smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? Why aren’t you in school?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: My heart aches. The boy takes off his T-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m in pain. It’s my chest, my heart. I’m worried.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: There’s no reason for you to be worried.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m worried because it’s hereditary.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You're too young to be worried.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That’s what you said about my father. And he didn’t smoke, he ate a very healthy diet, he went swimming almost every day. He should have come out of that surgery alive but he died. I also smoke. I started smoking recently. (Touching his chest.) It hurts here. I hardly slept at all last night. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My mother was terribly worried. I slept in her bed. Steven attaches some electrodes to the boy’s chest. INT. HOSPITAL - STRESS TEST ROOM —- MORNING Martin is running on a treadmill. Wires are attached to h body. Steven measures Martin’s blood pressure while he ru INT. HOSPITAL - STEVEN’S OFFICE - MORNING Martin removes the electrodes from his body and puts his shirt back on.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: If I had hair on my chest and stomach, how would you attach these?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: We'd shave the hair off first.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: How long does it take for the hair to grow back?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. About a month, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Your son told me you have loads of hair under your arms, three times more than I do. And that you have a hairy belly and a hairy back.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I probably do have a bit more hair than you do because I’m older than you. But you’1l soon have more hair too. It’s all down to hormones.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Can I see? Please. Take off your shirt and show me, please. The doctor hesitates, but eventually complies. Martin sta at his body.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay, you do have more than me. But not three times more. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mum and I thought it would be nice if you came for dinner with us tonight, then we can watch the rest of the film. Is nine good for you?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, but I’m afraid I can’t make it tonight. I need to be home.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Can’t you get away for a couple of hours?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I'm afraid not. Some other time.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: My mother will be upset. I’11 tell you a secret, but don’t tell her I told you. I think she likes you. I mean she’s attracted to you. She says that’s not true, but I’m sure of it. And to be honest, I think you're perfect for each other. You'd make a great couple. She’s got a great body, you’ve seen that for yourself. She lost weight and now she’s has a really lovely figure.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Your mother is very beautiful, but the idea that she and I could ever be together is ludicrous. Let me remind you that I’m a married man and I love my wife very much, and my kids, and that we are very happy together. The boy looks at Steven, half sad and half angry. Tears w up in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And for your information, you're absolutely fine. There’s nothing wrong with you. But you really should stop smoking. Do you promise? Martin stands up.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: So we’re okay? There’s nothing wrong with me?  30 31 31.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You couldn’t be healthier. Now you'd better go because I’m late for my rounds. Let’s talk tomorrow or the day after and arrange to meet again. Steven heads towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I want you to buy me a motorbike. A white Honda CRF250. Will you?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: We'll talk about it next time we meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven and Matthew are standing over the steelhead trout. Matthew is gutting the fish. Steven watches him, drinking ginger beer from a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin is sitting by himself. He has finished his meal an staring out the window. The doctor is clearly late. The b checks his watch. He stares out the window again. His pho rings. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Yes. Where are you? I called you a hundred times, didn’t you see my calls? Yes I’m here, I’ve eaten already. Sorry I didn’t wait for you but I was starving. What do you mean? What do you mean you can’t? I got you an apple pie. At least come for a bit. You have to come. I’ve been waiting for over half an hour. Come for a bit. I can come closer to where you are. Where are you? Are you at the hospital? I’1l bring you the apple pie.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s so important? An operation? Are you at the hospital? What sort of incident? Not tomorrow, now. Not tomorrow. I can’t tomorrow, I have to study. Now. Listen to me. Just a minute. Where are you? Another beat.  32 32. Martin hangs up the phone. He looks annoyed. EXT. MATTHEW’S HOUSE - GARDEN - DAY Matthew is grilling pieces of trout on the barbecue. The garden is immaculate. At the back of the large, suburban house is a wooden deck. Anna is helping the anaesthetist’ wife, MARY, a woman of around 55, to set the table. Steve emerges from the house and sits in a chair. He looks ill ease. He picks up a glass of wine and holds it in his han but doesn’t drink.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I was inside, making a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: The fish is almost ready. Pass me a plate.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Do you need a hand?

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: No, that’s okay. I forgot to tell you. I saw that boy yesterday. Your son’s friend.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Martin?

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Yes, right. Martin. I couldn’t remember his name.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Where did you see him?

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: At the hospital. He was hanging around beside your car. It looked like he was waiting for you. I said hello, but he pretended not to see me.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: That's impossible. It can’t have been him.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Maybe I was mistaken. But it looked a lot like him.  33 33.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You should go see Anna and get your eyes checked. Take my piece off the grill, will you? I don’t like it overdone. INT. STEVEN’S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Steven is sitting on the sofa, stroking the dog. He is ea a sandwich. He feeds the dog some ham. The door opens and walks in.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Hello, darling. Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Choir practice.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Have you eaten?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Yes, I ate earlier.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You don’t have to take the dog for a walk. I took him out already. We got back a little while ago.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Okay. She puts her bag down by the door.

dialogues.speaker: KIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dad, do you know who I saw today?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Who, darling?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Martin.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Martin who?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Martin. That boy who came over the other day, the son of your ex- patient. He brought me back from choir practice on his friend’s motorbike. He’s really funny. I laughed so hard my ribs hurt.  34 35 34.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes, he is very funny. Kim, I don’t want you riding on motorbikes without a helmet.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: I was wearing a helmet. He gave me his.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you ask him to come in?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: I did, but he was in a hurry. He had to get home. Where’s Mum?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: She's taking a shower. Is there something you need?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: I’m going up to bed. She kisses Steven and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin is standing on the pavement opposite Steven’s hous He watches the house with a blank expression that betrays emotion. He is holding a helmet under his arm. His friend motorbike is parked beside him. It’s a red HONDA CRF. The light in the living room goes off. INT. STEVEN'S HOUSE - KITCHEN —- MORNING Steven, Anna and Kim are having breakfast. Bob is not the Steven seems agitated.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: “Good evening. Anna Murphy Eye Clinic, how may I help you?”

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: “Good evening. I’d like to make an appointment.”

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: “When for?”

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: “Certainly. Of course. When would you like to come in?”  36 35.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: “Certainly, when would you like to come in?”

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: “Today. It’s urgent.”

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: “Today is impossible.”

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: “Please describe your symptoms.” Then you come and talk to me and I tell you whether it’s urgent or not. Meanwhile, you ask them to hold while you check to see whether any appointments are available.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Did you wake up Bob?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I did. He just likes lying in bed for a bit before he gets up. Leave him be. Should I squeeze some more orange juice?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: He’ll be late. Have you seen the time? The school bus will be here any minute. Steven gets up and goes to get Bob out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is sitting on the edge of his bed. As soon as his fat enters the room, Bob turns to look at him. His face is pa He looks a little frightened.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Robert, do you have any idea what time it is? Get up and get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I can’t get up.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You have ten minutes to get washed, dressed and eat your breakfast. I’m not going to drive you to school and neither is your mother.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I can’t get up.  37 38 39 36.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Bob. Get up and get dressed and stop messing about. Steven goes to leave the room.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Dad. My legs. They’re numb. I can’t move them. I can’t stand up. Bob is on the verge of tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The garage door opens automatically. Steven lifts his son into the car. Anna helps him. She closes the back door of car and then gets into the driver's seat. EXT. HOSPITAL ENTRANCE —- MORNING Steven lifts Bob out of the car. He puts a hand around hi shoulder and practically carries his son into the hospita Anna follows them inside. INT. HOSPITAL - NEUROLOGIST’S OFFICE - MORNING DR. ANDREW NICHOLS, a neurologist, is examining Bob. The is lying on a hospital bed. His shoes are off. Steven is sitting in a chair, watching the whole procedure. He trie crack a joke to reassure his son.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I hope you washed your feet yesterday, Bob, because Dr. Nichols punishes boys who don’t wash between their toes. He gives them injections with big fat needles.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NICHOLS
dialogues.text: Bob's feet are just fine and he has lovely hair and he is very brave. He’s all grown up now. You know I had long hair when I was little, too. Just like Bob.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I didn’t know that. Really?

dialogues.speaker: DR. NICHOLS
dialogues.text: Yes, really. Only mine was curlier. Now then Bob, I want you to tell me where you are.  40 37.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’m at the hospital. In the neurology department.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NICHOLS
dialogues.text: That's absolutely right. And what day is it today?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NICHOLS
dialogues.text: Okay then. With this pin, I’m going to touch the soles of your feet and all your toes. I want you to tell me if you can feel it. Don’t be scared, I’m not going to prick you, I’m just going to touch you. Okay? Bob nods. DR. NICHOLS (CONT’D) Perfect. Bob can feel the pin under all his toes. DR. NICHOLS (CONT’D) Perfect. Now, look directly into my eyes for this one. As soon as you see a finger move, point to it. The neurologist spreads out his hands and fingers. Bob lo him in the eye without moving his head. Dr. Nichols moves finger on the left, then a finger on the right, then both fingers together. Bob points to the correct fingers every time. DR. NICHOLS (CONT’D) Okay, good. Now I’m going to test your sensations. I want you to tell me if this feels the same on both sides. He touches Bob on the left and right cheek, the left and right ear, the left and right temple. Bob nods each time. DR. NICHOLS (CONT’D) Now close your eyes as tight as you can. Okay. Show me your teeth. Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is waiting in the corridor. Steven and Bob go up to Bob is limping a little, but he can walk.  38.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Everything is absolutely fine. Andrew gave him a thorough neurological examination and he passed with flying colours. It’s nothing. You two go home and we’1l talk tonight. I won’t be late, my schedule is pretty light today. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Maybe he should have an MRI.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: There’s no need to bother with all that. He just got scared, that’s all. He’s absolutely fine. You’re absolutely fine, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I think there was probably some test at school today that we weren’t very well prepared for.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes, and he preferred to spend his day at the hospital with Andrew and us. Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Dad, aren’t you going to show me your office?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Another time, darling. I have to go down to the operating theatre right away. Steven kisses his son and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've have to go. See you tonight. Call me if you need anything. Bye bye.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Bye, darling. Anna leads Bob away.  4l 42 43 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna and Bob are walking towards the exit. The moment the step outside, Bob collapses to the ground. His mother ben down and tries to lift him up. She calls for help and two NURSES rush over. They lift Bob into a wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is lying inside an MRI machine. Steven and Anna watch from behind a glass window. Dr. Nichols is taking notes. INT. HOSPITAL - PATIENT’S ROOM - NIGHT Bob is sleeping. Anna sits beside him. Steven stands talk to Matthew. There is a second bed in the room, but it is empty.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: You don’t have to operate tomorrow. Cancel everything.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: No. Why would I cancel? The schedule would go haywire. There's no need. Anyway, it’s nothing. The door opens and Dr. Nichols walks in.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Any news, Andrew?

dialogues.speaker: DR. NICHOLS
dialogues.text: MRI and MRA both fine. Blood work came back good. Cardiogram, chest X- ray and carotid ultrasound all clear.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I told you. I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Thank goodness for that.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NICHOLS
dialogues.text: Has he been under any psychological stress lately? Exams at school maybe?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No, he wasn’t stressed, he was just fine. He’s always a bit anxious, but that’s just the way he is.  40.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NICHOLS
dialogues.text: In my opinion, he should stay in tomorrow as well so that we can keep an eye on him.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Maybe we should give him a PET scan?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I don’t think there’s any need for that, do you Andrew? Tomorrow he’1l be well enough to walk all the way home.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NICHOLS
dialogues.text: Yes, I don’t think that’s necessary at this point. Let’s see how things are tomorrow and take it from there. There’s nothing to worry about, in my opinion. You go home and we'll speak tomorrow. I’1l be here all day. Anna, it was great seeing you, even under these circumstances.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: And you, Andrew. How’s your daughter?

dialogues.speaker: DR. NICHOLS
dialogues.text: She got married last year. I’ma grandfather now.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Give her my love.

dialogues.speaker: DR. NICHOLS
dialogues.text: I will. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Andrew. Thanks for everything.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Do you want me to let them know that you won't be operating tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I said no. Don’t go on about it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: That won’t be necessary, Matthew. I'll come in the morning. I won't go in to the clinic. I’1l bring him those cinnamon doughnuts he loves so much.  44 45 41.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Yes, I’m sure he’1l be thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin is riding his friend’s motorbike. Kim sits behind holding on tight. Neither of them are wearing helmets. Ma focuses all his attention on the road. Tears are streamin down Kim’s face, but it’s impossible to tell whether it’s from the wind or if she’s crying for some other reason. EXT. STEVEN’S HOUSE - GARDEN - NIGHT Anna is watering the plants. Kim comes out into the garde

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: At Claire’s. Is Dad asleep?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: How’s Bob?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Bob is absolutely fine. They’ve just kept him in as a precaution. Kim looks at her mother for a while without saying anythi

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m fine. How do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: I mean are you tired?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m absolutely fine. A little tired, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: See you in the morning. Oh, and while Bob’s in the hospital, you’1l be responsible for watering the plants. Okay? Kim walks away without answering.  46 47 42. INT. HOSPITAL - CORRIDOR —- MORNING Steven, dressed in his white doctor’s coat, and Anna, hol a box of doughnuts, are walking down the corridor. It is hour at the hospital. They both greet various people as t walk along.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Did he go to the toilet? Did he get up?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: He hadn’t when I passed by about an hour ago. He didn’t want to.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: He didn’t want to pee or he hadn’t got up?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: He didn’t want to pee.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Could he get up?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: He was asleep. I didn’t want to drag him out of bed. They stop outside the door to Bob’s room. INT. HOSPITAL - PATIENT’S ROOM - MORNING Steven and Anna enter Bob’s room. Martin is already there sitting next to Bob’s bed. Martin stands up.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Good morning, Doctor. How are you Mrs. Murphy? I just came by to see Bob. Kim told me what happened.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Hello, Martin. How nice of you. Hi darling, good morning. Did your friend Martin come to see you? Bob does not reply.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’1ll leave you alone now so that you can spend time with him too. I have to go anyway. I’1ll come by and see him again some other time, for sure. I offered to help him go to the toilet but he didn’t want me to and he wet the bed. I brought some lemonade. Mum made it yesterday. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Try it and let me know what you think.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. Anna goes over to Bob.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Darling, do you know what’s in this box?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Cinnamon doughnuts, that’s what. Martin goes over to Steven. Anna pulls off the sheets and folds them up.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I'll be in the canteen. Come whenever you can.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I don’t think I’1l have time today, as you might imagine. We’ll talk some other time.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No. Today. Come to the canteen. Just for ten minutes. Don’t stand me up like last time. Goodbye Mrs. Murphy. Bye, Bob. Martin leaves. We hear Anna saying goodbye as we watch hi go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin is waiting in the hospital canteen. Steven appears The canteen is packed with doctors, nurses and patients, seated at the tables.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Coffee? Apple pie?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I’ve only got ten minutes. I have to be back upstairs in ten minutes max.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Okay. I’1l get straight to the point. I’ve brought you a present. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You've given me so many presents and I’ve never given you anything. I thought that was rude of me. So I decided to make amends. Close your eyes. Steven does not close his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please close your eyes. Steven, losing patience, closes his eyes. Martin places a small box in his hand. Steven opens his eyes and sees the box.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a Swiss army knife. The boy puts his hand over his mouth, mortified.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I shouldn’t have told you that. I messed it up. I ruined the surprise. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Thank you very much, Martin.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: What an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter. Thank you very much. A PARAMEDIC approaches the doctor.

dialogues.speaker: PARAMEDIC
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Hello, Justin.

dialogues.speaker: PARAMEDIC
dialogues.text: I got the car. Second-hand, but still. Blue. I couldn’t find it in silver.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: That’s great. You’ll have to take me for a ride in it soon.

dialogues.speaker: PARAMEDIC
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. See you later. The paramedic walks away.  45.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: That reminds me, did you do anything about that motorbike I wanted?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Martin, I have to get back upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: All right. I won’t keep you much longer, even though you are devoting less and less time to me lately. But that’s okay, I understand. I just wanted to say one more thing. I’m really sorry about Bob.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It’s nothing serious.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: No, it is. That critical moment we both knew would come someday, well, here it is. The time is now. You’ll see, things will be better for us all after this. You know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: No, I don’t. Listen, Martin, I don’t have time for this. I have to be upstairs. Steven stares at Martin in silence. The boy looks around make sure nobody can hear them, that nobody is sitting to close.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (speaking fast, almost without catching his breath) Okay, I’m going to tell you this as quickly as I can so that I don’t hold you up since I get that you don’t have much time and you have to go back up to the ward. I will make myself as clear as possible. Yes, it’s exactly what you think. Yes. That’s it. Just like you killed a member of my family, now you have to kill a member of your own family. To balance things out, understand? I’m not going to tell you who to kill of course, that’s for you to decide. But if you don’t do it, they all die. Bob will die. Kim will die. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And so will your wife. They will all get sick and die. One: paralysis of the limbs, two: refusal of food to the point of starvation, three: bleeding from the eyes, four: death. One, two, three, four. You’re not going to get sick, don’t worry. You just have to stay calm, that’s all. There, I said it. As quickly as I could. I hope I haven’t kept you too long. Oh and one more thing, but I'll be very quick. You only have a few days to decide who to kill. Once stage three kicks in - remember what stage three is? Bleeding from the eyes, that’s stage three - once the bleeding starts, they die in a matter of hours. Well, don’t let me keep you. I have nothing more to say. Unless you have any questions. Steven stares at Martin in silence. He is clearly furious picks up his mobile phone and keys.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Get up and get out of here and don’t you dare come back or call me ever again. Now. Before I hit you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: All right, I'll go. I have to go anyway, I have French class to get to. I was leaving anyway. But don’t get angry. There’s really no point getting mad at me. I told you. This will do us all good. You'll see.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: If you ever come anywhere near me, my wife, or my children again I will kill you, I swear.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: (loudly) But how will you kill me? Oh wait, I have an idea. Why don’t you operate on me? Several people turn and stare at the doctor. Steven gets and leaves. Martin calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you know if Kim’s going to come by today? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If she does, tell her I’1l be outside, at the main entrance. I’m going for a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two security guards escort Martin out of the building. He heads towards the exit without putting up a fight. He gla over his shoulder and then walks out, zipping up his jack and smoothing down his hair. INT. HOSPITAL - PATIENT’S ROOM - EVENING Anna is sitting on the empty bed next to her son’s bed. S is reading him a book. Steven comes in and sits in a chai He is restless.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Has he eaten?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No, he’s not hungry.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What do you mean he’s not hungry?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: He’s not hungry. Steven takes a doughnut out of the box. He reaches over a puts it near his son’s mouth.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Come on, darling. Eat a doughnut.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I don’t want it, dad.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You do, but you're afraid that your mother and I will tell you off for eating doughnuts. Come on, eat it. You have my permission. You have our permission. It’s okay for him to eat a doughnut, isn’t it Anna?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You heard your mother. Eat it. He prises Bobs lips open and shoves the whole doughnut in his mouth. Anna gets up and pulls Steven away from their  51 48.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Leave him alone. He doesn’t want it now. He’ll eat it later. Steven does not back down. He gestures for Anna to sit ba down.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: That’s right. Chew it a bit. Now swallow. Bob spits the doughnut out.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Leave him alone. He said he doesn’t want it now.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: He is going to eat it right now. He is completely run down, that’s why he keeps falling over and crawling around on all fours. He’s going to eat them, all of them. In five minutes flat, I want to see this whole box empty. Steven storms out of the room, slamming the door behind h as he goes. INT. HOSPITAL - DIRECTOR’S OFFICE - NIGHT Steven, Anna, Dr. Nichols and the HOSPITAL DIRECTOR are discussing Bob’s case. A FEMALE DOCTOR is standing beside them, along with Matthew. They have spread all of Bob’s t results out on the desk. The Hospital Director studies th test results thoroughly, in silence.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: He stopped eating today. He keeps vomiting. The Hospital Director looks up at Anna and then looks bac the test results.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Some of the tests need to be done again, in my opinion. They haven't found anything, it’s not possible.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: It’s been less than a day since his last tests. I don’t think the results will be any different. To be honest, I think what we have here is a clear case of some psychosomatic disorder.  52 53

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: I’m inclined to agree with Anna.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Shouldn’t we rule out all possible causes before we resort to the easy option of a psychosomatic disorder?

dialogues.speaker: DR. NICHOLS
dialogues.text: We already have ruled out everything else.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: I think with psychiatric treatment and psychological support everything will be fine. He will walk again and eat just fine.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Of course he will.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Anna, if Bob was short-sighted or had a cataract or glaucoma, then your opinion really would be valuable. But thankfully Bob’s eyesight is perfect. And I can honestly say that if he ever needed glasses, you'd be the first person I'd consult. But right now the boy can’t eat and is paralysed in both legs, so I’m afraid I’m not remotely interested in your medical opinion. Nobody says a word. Anna opens the door and leaves the ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kim puts on lipstick and brushes her hair in front of the mirror. She then sprays herself with a little too much perfume. INT. STEVEN'S HOUSE - KIM’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Kim and Martin are sitting on the bed, kissing. The bedro lights are on. Music is playing on the computer. Kim’s be made. Martin touches her breast.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Are you on your period?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: No. If you’re hungry we can order something later. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: KIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My parents will be home late and they’ve left me some money.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m not hungry. Kim stands up, strips down to her underwear and lies on t bed, beneath her swimsuit picture. Martin smiles. They kiss.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are the prettiest girl I’ve ever met. Your mother is making a big mistake not trusting you to work at the clinic. A huge mistake.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Why? Stay a bit longer. We can listen to some music.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I can’t, Kim. It’s late.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Are you mad at me because of my dad?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Don’t be stupid. I’m not mad at you at all. And I thought I’d made myself clear - I don’t feel angry at him, I feel sorry for him. I have to go because it’s late, that’s all. It’s as simple as that. Don’t be annoying, I thought you understood.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Martin, I love you so much. He hugs her but does not say it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is marching angrily down the corridor. Steven follow her, holding a file of papers.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about what happened in there.  55 56 57 51.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I’m just so exhausted and stressed and...

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: (interrupting) It’s okay.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You go home. I’m staying here.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I’m going to give him all the tests again. Every single one of them. I’m staying here. Go home.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Let’s go home and we'll talk it over again tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Just go. Go to Kim, she’s by herself. I’1l come later. Go.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Good night. Anna stands there watching Steven as he goes back towards patients’ ward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven pushes Bob along in a wheelchair. Bob looks groggy He’s half asleep. Steven marches manically up and down th hospital corridors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven takes blood from Bob. He gives the blood sample to nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob is lying inside the MRI machine. He disappears into t machine as Steven watches.  58 59 52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired but wired, Steven stands next to a doctor who is gi Bob an abdominal ultrasound.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Take a deep breath and hold it for a few seconds. Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven pushes Bob back to his room in the wheelchair. Bob shattered, so is Steven. Abruptly, Steven stops pushing t wheelchair, lifts Bob up with both hands, puts his arms around him and walks him down the corridor, with the drip trailing behind them. Steven lets go of Bob and he falls the floor. Steven picks him up again. He kneels down in f of his son.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Bob, why don’t we play a game?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What game?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I'll tell you a secret, something I’ve never told you before, and then you’1ll tell me one. And whoever tells the best secret wins. Okay? When I was your age I'd just started masturbating and I’d only just started ejaculating. Only a little, barely a drop. I was worried that I had some kind of problem because at school I'd heard all sorts of stories. Then one day when my father had had a lot to drink and my brothers were out and he was sleeping in the bedroom, I crept inside, put my hand on his penis and started stroking it until he ejaculated. The sheets got covered in sperm. I got scared and ran out. I’ve never told anybody that before. Now it’s your turn to tell me a secret. Bob stares at his father, dumbstruck. An awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I don’t know. I don’t have one.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: That's impossible, you must have one.  60 53.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Bob, if all this is just an act, you should know that if you tell me now, I won't punish you and neither will your mother. We won’t be angry with you either.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It’s not an act.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: But if it is an act and you don’t stop this stupid joke right this minute, your punishment won't just be no TV for a month. I will take my electric shaver and I will shave your head and I will make you eat your hair. I mean it, I will literally make you eat your hair. I’m not kidding.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It’s not an act. Steven puts Bob back into the wheelchair in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven is asleep at his desk. His hair is tousled and his is undone. The door opens and Anna walks in. Steven wakes Anna hands him a takeaway coffee. They don’t say anything Steven has nothing to report.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I brought you a clean shirt. She takes a shirt out of her bag and hangs it up inside t locker where Steven keeps his lab coat.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Anything to tell me? Steven shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hungry? Want me to bring you something to eat?  61 62 63 64 54.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: No, thank you. Maybe you were right. Maybe it’s all psychological.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Everything will be all right, you'll see. Trust me. We’re in this together and everything will be all right. Let’s go and get you something to eat and some fresh air and then we’ll go up and see the little one. INT. SCHOOL - REHEARSAL ROOM —- DAY Kim is singing in the choir. A middle-aged man, the CHOIRMASTER, is conducting the orchestra. Suddenly, Kim f down. At first, everybody around her carries on singing. fear ripples through the choir, everyone gradually falls silent and the music stops. The choirmaster rushes over t see what has happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is sitting outside Bob’s room, crying. Matthew hugs A nurse comes out of the room, pushing a food trolley. INT. HOSPITAL - PATIENT’S ROOM - AFTERNOON Kim and Bob are lying in adjacent beds. Steven is feeding pieces of fruit. Kim spits them out. Bob watches them, sl opening and closing his eyes. He looks as if he has just woken up. Their dinner plates lie untouched on trays.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Dad, I don’t want any fruit.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Just one bite. For me. Kim chokes and her face flushes. She spits out the piece apple that Steven has fed her. INT. HOSPITAL - PATIENT’S ROOM - EVENING A nurse inserts nasogastric feeding tubes into the noses both children. Kim has calmed down, but looks exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: I want to sleep.  65 55.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: All right, darling. What are you going to wear to Claire’s party, did you decide yet?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
