dialogues.text: No. I’m tired, Dad. Switch off the light. Steven goes to turn the light off. He spots a new MP3 pla on the bedside table.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Where did you get this? Did Mum give it to you?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: No. Martin did. He made me a playlist with some songs that he likes. That we both like.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: When did he give you this?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: I don’t remember. Good night, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven sits in his car, thinking. He opens the car door, out, and walks quickly and angrily across the road. He is outside Martin’s house. He sees a light on in the living room. The TV is blaring. Steven goes up to the front door rings the doorbell frantically. Nobody answers. He bangs the door with his fists.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Open the door. I know you’re in there. Open the door or I will smash it down. Martin. Open the door or I will smash it down and I will fuck you and your mother just the way you wanted. Steven tries to break in through the balcony doors, but doesn’t succeed.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If anything happens to my kids or my wife, you'll die in prison, do you hear me? You’ll die in prison.  56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is sitting on the steps outside the hospital. Steven stands beside her. He appears rather sheepish and speaks low voice. He avoids looking Anna in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: How old was his father when he died?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Had you been drinking that day?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: He had an arrhythmia, a stroke, and that was it.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I asked whether you’d been drinking, not how he died. How long has this been going on? How long have you been seeing this boy?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: About six months.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Where were you meeting?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: What does it matter?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Where were you meeting him?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: At a Burger King, then we'd drive to the seaside. He’s got issues, serious psychological issues. He always did. I knew he acted weird sometimes, but now he’s lost it completely, he’s become dangerous. We have to take precautions. Go to the police and take some precautions.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You're not going to the police. You're not going to tell anyone. There’s no point. We’1ll wait and see. Had you been drinking when you operated on his father?  67 68 69 57.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Only a little. That had nothing to do with the outcome. A surgeon never kills a patient. An anaesthetist can kill a patient, but a surgeon never can. For example, Matthew has made mistakes that led to the death of a patient, but I never have. Anna turns her head away. She doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think Bob is a little better today. He seemed in a better mood and he wasn’t so pale. Anna does not respond.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you tell me you were seeing him?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: At first I didn’t see him that often, it was only recently that we started meeting more regularly. I was going to tell you at some point. I felt sorry for him. I gave him some money. His mum is out of work.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m going upstairs. Anna gets up and leaves. Steven stands there for a while, alone with his thoughts. Then he follows his wife into th hospital. INT. STEVEN’S HOUSE- BATHROOM - DAY Steven takes a shower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven sits on the edge of his bed, naked and numb. His g is vacant - he looks completely blank. The room is relati dark. The curtains are drawn. Steven stands up and hurrie gets dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven emerges from the front door of his house and finds envelope on the doormat, with his name written on it. He opens the envelope.  70 58. Inside is the watch he had given Martin, with a note. One the watch straps is missing. Snapped off. Steven looks in the envelope for the missing piece of leather, but it is there. The note, written in very neat handwriting, reads: “Time shows no mercy. By the way, you were right. Metal straps are better. Leather straps break.” INT. HOSPITAL - PATIENT’S ROOM - DAY Anna is sitting next to Bob’s bed. Kim is lying on her ba on the other bed. She is playing a game on her mobile pho Her legs are covered from the knees up with a sheet. Her are pointed. Exhausted, Anna rests her head on the metal frame. She strokes Bob’s legs.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: When are we going home?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Tomorrow or the day after. We’1ll get all our tests done and when the doctors say so, we can go home.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: But you are doctors too. Tell them we can go home.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: We'll tell them, darling. Kim interrupts the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Mum, did Martin come by while I was sleeping? Anna stands up and looks at her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Can you turn me onto my side, please? Anna goes over, turns Kim onto her side and returns to he chair. Kim has her back to her mother now. They cannot ma eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: KIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Nine.  59.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Is Dad here?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No, he’ll be here soon. Would you like me to fetch you some juice?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: No. Don’t go anywhere. Stay here. Silence. Kim’s phone rings. She picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: KIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good morning. How are you? Aren’t you coming by? Okay. Just my mum, my father will be here soon. Yes. You're here? I can’t. Are you coming up to see me? (Kim laughs) You really think that’s possible? Well, let’s see. Okay. Okay. Kim’s toes uncurl. Her legs slowly start to move. Kim pul herself up and sits on the bed. She then stands up and wa over to the window.

dialogues.speaker: KIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Martin? Yes, I stood up. Yes, thank you. Can you see me? Yes, I’m at the window, I’m standing at the window. Can you see me? Kim waves with her right hand. Then she smoothes her hair down with both hands.

dialogues.speaker: KIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can’t see you, can you see me? I’m waving at you. Can you see me waving? Great. Yes. Anna gets up and walks over to the window.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Mum, I want to stand up like Kim. Why can she get up and I can’t?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: All right. I’m going back to bed now. I’m lying down now. Okay. Thank you. Me too. Next time you come, call me first so that I’m not sleeping. I’1l tell them. Me too. Bye. As Kim lies down, her legs seize up again and her toes cu back into the soles of her feet. Anna looks out of the window. She scans the people in the street, but she canno see Martin. Bob falls out of bed.  60.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Mum, I’m coming over to the window. Anna rushes over, picks Bob up, and puts him back into be

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You'll be able to soon, my darling. Kim is older than you, that’s why she can do it. Soon you’1l be strong enough to stand up too. Anna turns to look at Kim, who has her back to them and h face pressed up against the window.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who were you talking to?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Martin. He sends his regards.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I don’t want you talking with him ever again.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Because I said so. Kim does not respond.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you hear what I said?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: (under her breath) Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: I didn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes you did. What did you say, Kim? Anna grabs her daughter with both hands and shakes her ha Kim cries out in pain.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Mum, let go, you’re hurting me. I didn’t say anything. Anna lets Kim fall abruptly back down on the bed.  71 61.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m not like your father. You better watch your mouth. If that’s the way you want it, I’m confiscating your phone right here and now. That’1ll teach you to be rude to your mother.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Give me my phone back. Please.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You can forget it. A long beat of silence.

dialogues.speaker: KIM
dialogues.text: Don’t be scared, mum. Don’t get hysterical. It’s not that tragic. Sometimes your body hurts from not moving and you can’t sleep, that’s all. The important thing is to make sure you have everything you need within reach. That’s all. You’1l see. You won’t be able to move either, but you'll get used to it. Anna stares at her speechless and her anger morphs into f

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is talking to Steven. She is upset. He hugs her and tries to calm her down.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You’re tired. Go home and rest. I’m here now.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I’m not tired. I’m telling you the truth, I really saw it happen.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: It was just a coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: How can it be a coincidence? How come neither of them have been able to get up and walk until now?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Darling, listen to yourself.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Okay. It just means things are getting better. That’s all it means. That Kim is getting better. Go home and rest for a bit. Please.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: They’re not better. They’re worse.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: This afternoon there’ 11 be an emergency meeting of the medical board. Andrew and I took the initiative of inviting two outstanding specialists from the Presbyterian University Hospital of Columbia. They’ve already arrived from New York and I’m meeting them this afternoon to brief them about the case. One of them is actually a personal friend of the director. Dr. Johnston. You must have heard of him. He’s the best there is when it comes to paralytic disorders.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes. EXT. ANNA’S CAR — AFTERNOON Anna is driving. We can sense that contradicting thoughts going through her mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna pulls over outside Martin’s house. She looks at the house, trying to figure out whether anyone is home. She t a deep breath and gets out of the car. She hesitates for moment, looks around, then carries on walking up to the f door of Martin’s house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin opens the front door. He is home alone. He is wear a T-shirt and boxer shorts and holding a plate of spaghet His hair is wet and freshly combed.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Good evening. I’m not sure if you remember me.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Of course I remember you. How are you? Come in.  63.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna sits on the sofa. Martin brings her a glass of iced water.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. I'd like to have a talk with you. I won’t take up much of your time.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Of course. I’ve only got ten minutes because I have to get to my French class. What’s up?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: My husband told me about you and your father. Martin puts his plate of spaghetti down on the table. He looks at Anna and smiles faintly.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Did he also tell you about my mum?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, then maybe I’m not the one you should hear it from. Ever since your husband killed my father, he’s been flirting with my mother constantly. To be honest, she has feelings for him too. She really likes your husband's hands and the truth is he does have very beautiful hands. All doctors have nice, clean hands. You see, now that we only have each other, my mother and I are friends and we tell each other everything. So I told her that I have no problem if she wants to go ahead with it, and anyway, he seems like a nice guy. Why would I stand in the way of her trying to get her life back on track? I mean, I'll be gone ina few years. I’1l get a job and I'll be gone.  76 64.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Look, if my husband made a mistake, if out of negligence or I don’t know what he somehow caused this tragic thing to happen, I don’t understand why my children and I have to pay the price. Martin picks up his plate of spaghetti.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Not long after my dad died, someone told me that I eat spaghetti in exactly the same way he did, told me what an extraordinary impression this fact had made on him. “Look how the boy eats spaghetti,” he said. “Exactly the same way his father did. He sticks his fork in and twirls it around and around until the spaghetti is all twisted up and then he puts it in his mouth.” At the time, I thought I was the only one who ate spaghetti like that. Only my dad and me. I realised later, of course, that everyone eats spaghetti that way. They all stick their fork in and twirl it around. Martin stands up.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was really upset when I realised that, maybe even more upset than when they announced to me that he was dead. I don’t know if what is happening is fair, but it’s the closest thing to justice I can think of. But enough chit chat, time's getting on and if I’m late for class I’m done for. You have a good day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The medical council is underway. Anna, Steven, Matthew, t Hospital Director and Dr. Nichols are all present, as are VISITING CONSULTANTS. Anna looks defeated. She sits in a chair with her arms folded and watches the proceedings without saying a word. We cannot hear what is being said. watch the scene unfold through a window.  77 78 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hospital Director is saying goodbye to the visiting consultants. Steven and Anna also say goodbye. The consultants get into a car and drive off. The Hospital Director gives Steven a hug and pats him on the back.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: So, I don’t see any reason for the children to stay in hospital.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You mean you think you’ve done everything you can?

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Yes, Steven, I believe we have done everything we can.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Sorry, but if I was running this hospital I would feel like a complete failure. A loser. I wouldn’t be able to sleep at night. The Hospital Director looks at Steven then walks away.

dialogues.speaker: HOSPITAL DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Good night, Anna.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Good night, Ed. Anna looks at her husband.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I suggest you sign the release forms tomorrow and then they can go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna marches angrily along the corridor. Steven follows, trying to catch up. Suddenly, Anna falls over. Steven pan Anna gets back up.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: I tripped. It’s nothing. My shoelace was undone. I tripped. She gets up and carries on walking, leaving Steven standi there. She is almost running.  79 66. INT. CAFETERIA —- MORNING Anna is sitting at a table, waiting. The cafeteria is alm empty. It doesn’t seem like the kind of place where Anna would normally choose to go. She is well dressed, but loo drained. Matthew comes over to the table. He kisses Anna the cheek and sits opposite her. She wavers for a moment before she starts speaking.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Good evening, Anna.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Good evening, Matthew. Sorry to bother you.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: It’s no bother, really.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: As I said on the phone, I'd rather Steven didn’t find out about us meeting like this.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: He won’t. I’m listening.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Four years ago, you were operating as a team, weren’t you? I mean four years ago, you were the anaesthetist on some of Steven’s operations?

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Were you the anaesthetist for Jonathan Lang? Matthew leans back in his chair and pretends rather unconvincingly that he is trying to place the patient’s n The waiter arrives with the coffee that Anna has ordered. Their conversation is interrupted.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: A gin and tonic, please. The waiter leaves.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who’s Jonathan Lang?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Male, 46 years old, one of Steven's patients. He died on the operating table.  67.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Anna, there have been so many patients over the years, so many operations. I don’t remember him, I’m afraid. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Can you find his file in the records and bring it to me, please? I'll give it straight back to you. I just want to have a look at his medical history. And the cause of death.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: I don’t think that will be possible. I’m sorry, Anna. I can’t just take a file from the hospital. Why do you need it?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Look, I can’t bring you the file but I can tell you a couple of things about the case. I remember him now, I put him under. But what do I get in return?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What you didn’t get that day we came for lunch.

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Now. Had Steven been drinking?

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Can it be considered his mistake?

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW
dialogues.text: Yes. It definitely wasn’t mine, that’s for sure. You know an anaesthetist is never to blame for the bad outcome of an operation. The surgeon is responsible. He’d had two drinks that morning before we went in to prepare. Luckily none of the others realised, I was the only one who knew. But that wasn’t exactly unusual back then. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: MATTHEW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know that. He was drunk during almost every operation.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Do you remember Lang’s case history? Matthew leans forward in his chair again and rests his ar on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matthew’s car is parked on a deserted road on the edge of town. There are no pedestrians and very few cars. Anna st straight ahead as she jerks off the anaesthetist. He push his seat back to the reclining position. As soon as he co he pulls the chair forward, starts the engine, and they d off. EXT. STEVEN’S HOUSE - FRONT DOOR - AFTERNOON The front door is open. The children are being carried in the house with the help of two paramedics. Steven seems fairly optimistic as he manically rushes about, supervisi the procedure. INT. KIM’'S BEDROOM - AFTERNOON Kim's bedroom has been rearranged to accommodate both the children’s beds. The room is bright, the curtains have be pulled back to let in the sunlight. Anna changes the feed solution in Bob and Kim’s Levin tubes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven and Anna are having dinner. He is the only one eat Anna toys with the wedges of potato on her plate with her fork. Steven watches her intently, trying to get a reacti but she remains stubbornly silent. Steven fills Anna’s gl with wine. She does not say thank you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: This meat is delicious. His wife does not respond.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were right after all. The children are much better off here. I was even thinking we might take them to the beach house for a few days. A little fresh air anda change of scenery might do us all good.  69. Anna looks up and stares at her husband, as if she were observing him for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: One of these days you’re going to have to go in to their school and excuse their absence. They want you to sign some papers. They've called lots of times.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I will. You know what I’ve been craving? Mashed potatoes. Why don’t you make some tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You've got beautiful hands. I'd never noticed before. Everyone's been telling me lately what beautiful hands you have and now I can see it for myself. Nice and clean. But so what if they’re beautiful? They’re lifeless. Sometimes, Steven, you’re just an incompetent man with hands that don’t move who just goes on and on, saying stupid things. “Let’s do a scan, let’s do a gastroscopy, let’s make mashed potatoes, let’s wear brown socks, let’s go to the beach house.”

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Our two children are dying in their beds but yes, I can make you mashed potatoes tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Please don’t talk to me that way.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: If you don’t like it why don’t you go and live with Martin’s mother, I bet she’d talk to you nicer. Steven does not take the bait.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You wanted the kids to come home and they’re home. What else do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Do something to put an end to all this, that’s what. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s what I want. Can you do that? You do realise Steven that we've ended up in this situation because of you?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: So what do you suggest? Tell me. Oh, wait, I know, I’ve got it. There is a way that we can put a stop to all this. All we need to do is find the tooth of a baby crocodile, the blood of a pigeon, and the pubes of a virgin and then we just have to burn them all before sunset. Let me see, do we have any spare teeth lying around? Steven starts opening cupboards and flinging packets of f onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Teeth, pubes, nope, nothing in here, or here. Nothing in this box either. Where are they? I was sure they were here somewhere. I put them here myself. Who keeps moving things around? Unbelievable. I don’t supposed you’ve got any pubes I could have, by any chance? Oh I forgot, you don’t have any left. We don’t have any of the things we need. Well, that’s a shame. I guess there’s nothing I can do. Steven stalks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven is setting the alarm clock.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: There’s no need for us to argue. Everything's so difficult already, there’s no point making it worse. Anna does not respond. She lies down on the bed without covering herself up and turns her back to Steven.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If he was telling the truth, wouldn't you be sick too? Wouldn't you be paralysed already? How do you explain that?  85 86 71.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Yes, you're right. Let’s wait a bit longer until we’re all dead and then we’‘ll see what you can do about it. There’s really nothing to worry about. A short, awkward beat of silence.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go to the hospital tomorrow and pick up some feeding formula for the children. We’re almost out.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Okay. Steven turns to look at his wife. Anna turns out the ligh Steven lies beside her in the darkness with his eyes wide open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven is standing in the middle of the room, smoking. He alone. He sits in an armchair. After a few moments, he st up again. Taking care not to make any noise, he picks up car keys and coat and quietly shuts the door. INT. STEVEN'S HOUSE - BEDROOM — MORNING Anna is lying in bed with her eyes open. Steven enters th room. He stands beside her. He sits on the edge of the be and takes her hand. She does not react.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Did you get any sleep?

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Ten past eight. Get up and come with me for a moment. Anna gets up.  87 72.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven and Anna head down to the basement. Steven unlocks door. They enter a fairly large room full of random garde furniture. It is dark and dirty. The light goes on - a sm bulb that faintly illuminates the space - and we see Mart huddled in a corner. He is sitting in an old armchair. Hi feet are bound together with gaffer tape and he is chaine a pipe in the corner of the room. His hands are tied in f of him. Martin’s face is bloodied and swollen. There is a rifle on the table. Anna looks at Martin and then walks over to the table. Sh turns to face Steven. Anna does not move. She looks at Martin. Martin looks up holds her gaze. It’s hard to tell whether he is angry or afraid. He raises his hand and wipes some blood off the s of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You remember Martin, don’t you? He came over for a play date, but I told him the kids are feeling a little unwell, so he’ll just have to wait here until they get better. Anna, go upstairs and make me some of that lemonade he likes so much, would you? I’ll stay here and keep him company. Off you go. Anna hesitates and then leaves. She closes the basement d behind her. We hear her footsteps on the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Let me go. My mother will be worried sick.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Do you think your mother is proud of you, Martin? Do you think she is happy that her beloved son is a murderer?

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Murderer. There’s no need for such a dramatic, sensational, old- fashioned word. But if you insist, the murderer, both in my father’s case and our current situation, is not me.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Stop talking.  88 73.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Don’t you understand that you’re wasting time? You don’t have much time left.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I said stop talking.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Steven, you’ll feel better once it’s done. You can start over, a clean slate, don’t you get it? Sometimes I think you might just be a fool who can’t understand the significance of the gift I am offering. Sometimes I think you’re naive. But you can’t be. You’re a good scientist, you can’t be an idiot. If I’d only just met you I’d seriously question the depth of your judgement. Steven strikes the boy across the face. Martin grabs his and holds it tight.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t move. I just want to give you an example, that’s all. I’1l give you one little example so that you understand what I mean. Martin bites Steven’s arm. Blood trickles down his hand. Steven screams.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Should I apologise? No. Should I stroke your wound? No way. That would probably hurt even more, touching an open wound. No. There’s only one way to make you and me both feel better. Martin bites his own arm and spits out a small piece of flesh. His face is contorted with pain but he doesn’t scr He tries to remain composed.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you understand? It’s metaphorical, my example. A metaphor. I mean, it’s symbolic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna is scrubbing the blood from the back seat of Steven' car. The dog watches her but she doesn’t pay him any attention. We hear a muffled gunshot. The dog starts to b  89 90 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anna opens the door. Steven has shot Martin in the leg. H still holding the gun and pointing it at Martin. The boy writhes in agony.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Shut the door, Anna. Now Martin, you'll see what it’s like to die. What it’s like when your head cracks open and your brains are blown out.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Steven, don’t shoot him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: And then?

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Shut up.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: Shoot me. Then what? Answer me.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I‘1l bury you in the garden and you'll decompose. That’s what.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: You won’t be able to explain it. You won’t understand how it could have happened. You’ll say - “But I only killed one person, how come four people are dead? I only shot one.” You’ll get confused and you'll start counting again: one, two, three. But the numbers still won't add up. If you dig a hole in the garden, better make it a big one. dialogues.speaker: BOB

dialogues.text: Good boy, well done.

dialogues.speaker: BOB

dialogues.speaker: BOB, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you want me to water the plants? Steven goes to him and hugs him.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: No, darling. I watered them this morning. Tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Dad, I’ve been thinking about it and I’ve decided I want to be a cardiologist, not an ophthalmologist. I lied to mum because I didn’t want her to get upset. I think I prefer what you do, it’s far more interesting and challenging.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: No. Not to me it isn’t.  93 94 95 96 77. INT. - STEVEN'S HOUSE - KIM’S BEDROOM - EVENING Steven lays his son in his bed. He tucks him in and strok his hair. EXT. He closes the French windows and switches off the living room light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steven is waiting outside the Headmaster’s office. The HEADMASTER’'S SECRETARY ushers him inside. Steven gets up enters the office. INT. SCHOOL - HEADMASTER’S OFFICE - MORNING Steven is sitting in a chair, signing some papers. He giv them to the HEADMASTER.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: Sorry for the trouble, dragging you down here. It’s all just a formality, but it has to be done.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: That’s quite all right. I understand.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: All the staff and I personally hope that all this is only temporary and that the children will soon be back at school in good health.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. They’re already much better now that they’re back home. However, I must inform you that they will need to be off school for a little while longer.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: Whatever you think is best. If you feel they are not in a position to attend class yet, very well. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: However, do bear in mind that in cases like this it’s generally best for children not to disrupt their daily routine for too long. Attending even some of their classes might do them good. Of course, it’s ultimately your decision. All I can do is share my thoughts with you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. But as you know both my wife and I are doctors, and we are quite able to judge when our children are ready to return to school.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: Of course. I hope everything works out well.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: I'm very optimistic. Everything will be fine.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: That's the spirit. Steven gets up to go.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Generally speaking, if you had to compare the two children for some reason, which of the two would you consider the better student?

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: Well. The boy is very good at maths and physics. Kim on the other hand, apart from her natural aptitude for music, is pretty good at literature and history, areas in which Bob lags behind. She wrote a brilliant essay on the tragedy of Iphigenia which she read out in class. At.

dialogues.text: What about their behaviour in class?

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: They're both a little restless, equally so. I mean I’ve had the occasional complaint from their teachers about some minor misdemeanors, but they’ve never been rude to any of the staff. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In any case, if they had ever acted in an inappropriate way we would have informed you about it.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Do you especially like one of them more than the other? If you had to choose between them, which would you say is the best?

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: That's a difficult question. I’m not sure I can give you an answer. The Headmaster considers his response for a long time. He doesn’t know what to say. Steven has put him in an extrem uncomfortable position. Steven stares at the Headmaster intently, as if his response has enormous significance. HEADMASTER (CONT’D) I don’t know. He thinks about it some more. HEADMASTER (CONT’D) I don’t know what to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Never mind. Have a good day.

dialogues.speaker: HEADMASTER
dialogues.text: Goodbye. Steven leaves the Headmaster’s office.

dialogues.text: Anna unlocks the door and enters the room, holding Bob in arms. Kim drags herself along beside them. The childre watch the procedure from a distance.

dialogues.text: Thank you for bringing them down. I really wanted to see them. I really wanted to see you. Hi Kim. Hi Bob. Come over here and let me give you a kiss. Kim hobbles over to Martin. He kisses her on the lips. Bo doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bob, aren't you going to come over and give me a kiss? No?  98 99 80.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: Bob? Bob struggles towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter, I understand. You're a man, you are the man of the house now that your father isn’t home. Now go back to bed. Don’t trouble yourselves any more for my sake. Take them away. Anna carries the children out. She leaves the door open.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anna. If you're going to do something, you need to do it fast. The boy is about to die.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA
dialogues.text: You do have beautiful hands. Steven does not react.

dialogues.speaker: ANNA, (CONT'D)

If you have to kill someone, the logical thing, no matter how harsh this may sound, is to kill a child. Because we can have another child. I still can and so can you. And if you can’t, we can try IVF. But I’m sure we can. Steven says nothing. He switches off the bedside lamp.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Go to sleep. INT. STEVEN’S HOUSE - BASEMENT - NIGHT Martin is lying in a corner of the basement. The key turn the lock. The door opens and Kim drags herself into the r on all fours.  100 101 102 81.

dialogues.text: They’re all asleep. We can go now and nobody will notice. All you have to do is help me walk again. My legs hurt after all this time and I feel weak. But it’s okay, it doesn’t matter. I knew at some point this would all be over and you would come. Martin looks at Kim, but doesn’t say anything.

dialogues.speaker: KIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought we could take your friend’s motorbike and go away together. But you have to make me well first. Okay? I’1l untie you if you promise I'll get better and we can run away. Okay? Martin continues to stare at her in silence. Kim tries to stand up, but can’t.

dialogues.speaker: KIM, (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: KIM, (CONT'D)

You are my lords, my masters and I am just someone who lives to obey your wishes. I love you so much, don’t forget that. Remember that when I’m in my grave, unable to tell you that I love you. dialogues.speaker: ANNA

STEVEN'S HOUSE - CHILDREN’S BEDROOM - NIGHT Anna sits on the edge of Bob’s bed. She has a washbowl ne to her and cleans Bob’s limbs with a cloth. dialogues.text: Please describe your symptoms. I see. Would you be so kind as to hold the line while I check the doctor's availability? Yes, sorry to keep you waiting. dialogues.text: Kim is sitting in a chair in a corner of the room. Anna i standing by the wall, near the French windows. Bob is on sofa. He can barely sit up. They all look terrified. dialogues.text: Steven is sitting in a Burger King with Anna and Kim. Mar walks in, limping from the bullet wound. He stares at the he walks past and sits at a table nearby. Steven and Anna watch Martin out of the corner of their eye. They both lo haggard. Kim puts ketchup on her chips and starts wolfing them down. She looks healthy. Her parents watch her eat. Kim has finished eating her chips, they put on their jack and go to leave. Kim stands up, takes a quick look at Mar and then follows her parents. She is walking normally.
